WANT TO SEE YOUR FACE NO MORE...
COME A HANGIN' AROUND MY DOOR... I DON'T
AMERICAN WOMAN, MAMA LET ME BE... DON'T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On VIDEO: JANE BURNHAM lays in bed, wearing a tank top. S sixteen, with dark, intense eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a father who's a role model, not some horny geek-boy who's gonna spray his shorts whenever I bring a girlfriend home from school. (snorts) What a lame-o. Somebody really should put him out of his misery. Her mind wanders for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to kill him for you? Jane looks at us and sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Yeah, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're FLYING above suburban America, DESCENDING SLOWLY to a tree-lined street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Lester Burnham. This is my neighborhood. This is my street. This... is my life. I'm forty-two years old. In less than a year, I'll be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking down at a king-sized BED from OVERHEAD: LESTER BURNHAM lies sleeping amidst expensive bed linens, face down, wearing PAJAMAS. An irritating ALARM CLOCK RIN Lester gropes blindly to shut it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I don't know that yet. He rolls over, looks up at us and sighs. He doesn't seem too thrilled at the prospect of a new day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in a way, I'm dead already. He sits up and puts on his slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester thrusts his face directly into a steaming hot show ANGLE from outside the shower: Lester's naked body is silhouetted through the fogged-up glass door. It becomes apparent he is masturbating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) Look at me, jerking off in the shower. (then) This will be the high point of my day. It's all downhill from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a single, dewy AMERICAN BEAUTY ROSE. A gloved ha with CLIPPERS appears and SNIPS the flower off. CAROLYN BURNHAM tends her rose bushes in front of the Bur house. A very well-put together woman of forty, she wears color-coordinated gardening togs and has lots of useful a expensive tools. Lester watches her through a WINDOW on the first floor, peeping out through the drapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my wife Carolyn. See the way the handle on those pruning shears matches her gardening clogs? That's not an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the fenced front yard of the house next door, a dog BA repeatedly. A MAN in a conservative suit (JIM #1) chastis the barking dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush, Bitsy. You hush. What is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's our next-door neighbor Jim. A second MAN in a conservative suit (JIM #2) comes out of house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's his lover, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: barking dog) What in the world is wrong with her? She had a walk this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a jerky treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spoil her. (sternly) Bitsy. No bark. Come inside. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester watches all this from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Jim! Jim #1 walks toward the fence to greet Carolyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Carolyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overly friendly) I just love your tie! That color!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just love your roses. How do you get them to flourish like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll tell you. Egg shells and Miracle Grow. Jim #1 and Carolyn continue to chat, unaware that Lester watching them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man. I get exhausted just watching her. Lester's POV: We can't hear what Jim and Carolyn are sayi but she's overly animated, like a TV talk show host.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't always like this. She used to be happy. We used to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE is seated at her desk, working at her computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter Jane. Only child. CLOSE on the COMPUTER MONITOR: A PERSONAL BANKING SOFTWAR window suddenly disappears to reveal another window: a PLASTIC SURGERY WEBSITE, featuring clinical "before" and "after" photos of surgically augmented breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie's a pretty typical teenager. Angry, insecure, confused. I wish I could tell her that's all going to pass... Outside, a CAR HORN BLARES. Jane stuffs items into her BACKPACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I don't want to lie to her. We HEAR the CAR HORN again from outside. Jane studies her in a mirror, then shifts to get a good profile of her breasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn stands next to a platinum-colored MERCEDES-BENZ ML320, reaching in through the drivers' window to blow th HORN again. Jane shuffles out of the house, her backpack slung over h shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane. Honey. Are you trying to look unattractive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations. You've succeeded admirably. Jane gets in the car. Lester hurries out the front door, carrying a BRIEFCASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester, could you make me a little later, please? Because I'm not quite late enough. Lester's briefcase suddenly springs open and his papers s all over the driveway. He drops to his knees to gather everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice going, Dad. Lester smiles sheepishly, trying to lighten the moment. His POV: Carolyn looks down at us, contemptuous but also bored, as if she gave up expecting anything more long ago

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both my wife and daughter think I'm this gigantic loser, and... they're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn is driving; Jane stares out the window. Lester is asleep in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have lost something. I'm not exactly sure what it is, but I know I didn't always feel this... sedated. But you know what? It's never too late to get it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester sits at his workstation, a BEIGE CUBICLE surrounde IDENTICAL BEIGE CUBICLES. He's staring at a computer moni and talking on a HEADSET PHONE. The beleaguered expressio his face is at odds with the light, friendly tone of his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Lester Burnham from Media Monthly magazine, I'm calling for Mr. Tamblin, please?... Well, we're all under a deadline here, uh, but you see, there is some basic information about the product launch that isn't even covered in your press release and I... Yeah. Can I ask you a question? Who is Tamblin? Does he exist? 'Cause he doesn't ever seem to come in... Yeah, okay, I'll leave my number...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BRAD, a dapper man in his thirties, approaches and observ Lester, who is unaware of his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 555 0199. Lester Burnham. Thank you! Lester disconnects the call, obviously irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Les. You got a minute? Lester turns around, smiling perfunctorily

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you, Brad? I've got five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad is seated behind his desk in his big corner office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you can understand our need to cut corners around here. Lester sits across from him, looking small and isolated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. Times are tight, and you gotta free up cash. Gotta spend money to make money. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. So... Brad stands, ready to usher Lester out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blurts) Like the time when Mr. Flournoy used the company MasterCard to pay for that hooker, and then she used the card numbers and stayed at the St. Regis for, what was it, like, three months?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) That's unsubstantiated gossip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fifty thousand dollars. That's somebody's salary. That's somebody who's gonna get fired because Craig has to pay women to fuck him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Calm down. Nobody's getting fired yet. That's why we're having everyone write out a job description, mapping out in detail how they contribute. That way, management can assess who's valuable and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's expendable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) I've been writing for this magazine for fourteen years, Brad. You've been here how long, a whole month?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frank) I'm one of the good guys, Les. I'm trying to level with you. This is your one chance to save your job. Lester stares at him, powerless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MOVING VAN is parked in front of the COLONIAL HOUSE nex door to the Burnhams'. Movers carry furniture toward the house. The Mercedes-Benz pulls into the Burnham driveway. Caroly drives, Lester is in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --there is no decision, you just write the damn thing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think it's weird and kinda fascist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly. But you don't want to be unemployed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, let's just all sell our souls and work for Satan, because it's more convenient that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you be just a little bit more dramatic, please, huh? As they get out of the car, Carolyn scopes out the MOVERS next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we've finally got new neighbors. You know, if the Lomans had let me represent them, instead of-- (heavy disdain) --"The Real Estate King," that house would never have sat on the market for six months. She heads into the house, followed by Lester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they were still mad at you for cutting down their sycamore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their sycamore? C'mon! A substantial portion of the root structure was on our property. You know that. How can you call it their sycamore? I wouldn't have the heart to just cut down something if it wasn't partially mine, which of course it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR EASY-LISTENING MUSIC. Lester, Carolyn and Jane are eating dinner by CANDLELIGHT RED ROSES are bunched in a vase at the center of the tabl Nobody makes eye contact, or even seems aware of anybody else's presence, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, do we always have to listen to this elevator music?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (considers) No. No, we don't. As soon as you've prepared a nutritious yet savory meal that I'm about to eat, you can listen to whatever you like. A long beat. Lester suddenly turns to Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Janie, how was school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suspicious) It was okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Dad. It was spec-tac-ular. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you want to know how things went at my job today? Now she looks at him as if he's lost his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've hired this efficiency expert, this really friendly guy named Brad, how perfect is that? And he's basically there to make it seem like they're justified in firing somebody, because they couldn't just come right out and say that, could they? No, no, that would be too... honest. And so they've asked us-- (off her look) --you couldn't possibly care any less, could you? Carolyn is watching this closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Well, what do you expect? You can't all of a sudden be my best friend, just because you had a bad day. She gets up and heads toward the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, hello. You've barely even spoken to me for months. She's gone. Lester notices Carolyn looking at him critica

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what, you're mother-of-the-year? You treat her like an employee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) What?! Lester is quiet, staring at his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more authority) What? Lester gets up and starts after Jane, taking his plate wi him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get some ice cream. Carolyn watches him go, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane stands at the sink, rinsing off her plate. Lester enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm sorry. I... Jane turns and stares at him, waiting for him to finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I haven't been more available, I just... I'm... He's looking to her for a little help here, but she's too uncomfortable with this sudden intimacy to give him any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) You know, you don't always have to wait for me to come to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great. So now it's my fault?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that. It's nobody's fault. Janie, what happened? You and I used to be pals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On VIDEO: We're looking through GREENHOUSE WINDOWS at Les and Jane in the kitchen We can't hear what they're saying but it's obvious it's not going well.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jane puts her plate in the dishwasher and leaves. We FOLL HER out the door, then the camera JERKS back to Lester calling after her. CLOSE on the face of   RICKY FITTS, illuminated by the sc of his DIGICAM as he   videotapes. Ricky is eighteen, but eyes are much older.   Beneath his Zen-like tranquility l something wounded...   and dangerous. His POV, on VIDEO: Through the kitchen window, we see Les at the sink, rinsing off his plate, muttering to himself. head suddenly jerks up and he looks at us, as if he reali he's being watched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester's POV: We're looking out through the kitchen windo the point where Ricky was just standing, but he's no long there. Lester turns off the faucet, dries his hands, then tosses towel on the counter on his way out, where it lands next framed PHOTOGRAPH of Lester, Carolyn, and a much-younger Jane, taken several years earlier at an amusement park. It's startling how happy they look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a wooden SIGN that reads:

dialogues.speaker: OPEN HOUSE TODAY
dialogues.text: BURNHAM & ASSOCIATES REALTY 555-0195 Carolyn Burnham The sign is planted in front of a RUN-DOWN HOME in a   ru neighborhood. The Mercedes is parked in front of the   ho Carolyn, wearing a smart business suit, is unloading   a cleaning supplies and a BOOMBOX from the back of the   Me when something across the street catches her eye. Her POV: In front of a different house with much more cur appeal is another SIGN, featuring a picture of a handsome silver-haired MAN. It reads: Another One SOLD By Buddy Kane The Real Estate King 555-0100 Carolyn frowns and slams the back of the Mercedes shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of this house is ugly, oppressive and tastel Carolyn opens the front door, breathes deeply and solemnl announces:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will sell this house today. She neatly arranges her sales materials on a desk, then strips down to her undergarments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Carolyn, working with fierce concentration as she: Cleans glass doors that overlook the patio and pool; Doggedly scrubs countertops in the kitchen; Perches on a stepladder to dust a cheap-looking ceiling f in the master bedroom; And vacuums a dirty carpet that will never be clean. Throughout all this, she keeps repeating to herself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will sell this house today. I will sell this house today. I will sell this house today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn stands in front of the mirror, wearing her suit o more, applying lipstick. She stares at her reflection critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will sell this house today. She says this as if it were a threat, then notices a smud on the mirror and wipes it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens to reveal Carolyn, greeting us with smile she thinks could sell ice to an Eskimo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome. I'm Carolyn Burnham!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiling, Carolyn leads a man and woman into the living ro They're thirtyish, and they've seen a lot of houses today

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This living room is very dramatic. Wait 'til you see the native stone fireplace! The man and woman glance around the dark room, unimpresse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple cream would really lighten things up. You could even put in a skylight. The woman wrinkles her face, skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, why don't we go into the kitchen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn enters, followed by a different couple in their fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a dream come true for any cook. Just filled with positive energy. Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn stands with a different couple: African American, late twenties. The woman is pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you'll be surprised how much a ceiling fan can cut down on your energy costs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn stands by the pool next to two fortyish WOMEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you could have some really fun backyard get-togethers out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ad said this pool was "lagoon-like." There's nothing "lagoon-like" about it. Except for maybe the bugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not even any plants out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: shrub) What do you call this? Is this not a plant? If you have a problem with the plants, I can always call my landscape architect. Solved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I think "lagoon," I think waterfall, I think tropical. This is a cement hole. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some tiki torches in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn enters, alone. She's furious. She locks the slidi glass door and starts to pull the vertical blinds shut, t stops. Standing very still, with the blinds casting shado across her face, she starts to cry: brief, staccato SOBS seemingly escape against her will. Suddenly she SLAPS herself, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. Stop it. You... Weak! But the tears continue. She SLAPS herself again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weak. Baby. Shut up. Shut up! Shut up! She SLAPS herself repeatedly until she stops crying. She stands there, taking deep breaths until she has everythin under control, then pulls the blinds shut, once again all business. She walks out calmly, leaving us alone in the d empty room. We HEAR CHEERING and APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at a high-school BASKETBALL GAME. Teenage boys play fast and furious game. One team wearing pale blue and whi uniforms scores a basket. Perky cheerleaders jump up and as the CROWD goes wild.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Seated in the bleachers, next to the high school BAND, is group of about twenty TEENAGE GIRLS, dressed in pale blue white uniforms. Among them, Jane sits next to ANGELA HAYE At sixteen, Angela is strikingly beautiful; with perfect features, blonde hair and a nubile young body, she's the archetypal American dream girl. Jane stands and scans the bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My parents are coming tonight. They're trying to, you know, take an active interest in me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gross. I hate it when my mom does that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're such assholes. Why can't they just have their own lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carolyn drives. Lester is slumped in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure she wants us to be there? Did she ask us to come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not. She doesn't want us to know how important this is to her. But she's been practicing her steps for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I bet money she's going to resent it. And I'm missing the James Bond marathon on TNT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lester, this is important. I'm sensing a real distance growing between you and Jane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing? She hates me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just willful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hates you too. Carolyn stares at him, unsure of how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uniformed girls now stand in formation on the gym flo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over P.A.) And now, for your half-time entertainment, Rockwell High's award- winning Dancing Spartanettes! In the crowded stands, Lester and Carolyn find seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can leave right after this, right? The HIGH SCHOOL BAND plays "ON BROADWAY." On the gym floo the girls perform. They're well-rehearsed, but too young carry off the ambitious Vegas routine they're attempting. Lester, watching from the stands, picks out his daughter. His POV: Jane performs well, concentrating. Dancing awkwa next to her is Angela. Suddenly Angela looks right at us smiles... a lazy, insolent smile. Lester leans forward in his seat. His POV: We're focused on Angela now. Everything starts t SLOW DOWN... the MUSIC acquires an eerie ECHO... We ZOOM slowly toward Lester as he watches, transfixed. His POV: Angela's awkwardness gives way to a fluid grace, "ON BROADWAY" FADES into dreamy, hypnotic MUSIC. The ligh Angela grows stronger, and the other girls DISAPPEAR entirely. Lester is suddenly alone in the stands, spellbound. His POV: Angela looks directly at us now, dancing only fo Lester. Her movements take on a blatantly erotic edge as starts to unzip her uniform, teasing us with an expressio that's both innocent and knowing, then... she pulls her uniform OPEN and a profusion of RED ROSE PETALS spill forth... and we SMASH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela, fully clothed, is once again surrounded by the ot girls. The HIGH SCHOOL BAND plays its last note, the Danc Spartanettes strike their final pose, and the audience APPLAUDS. Carolyn claps along with the rest of the audience. Lester just sits there, unable to take his eyes off Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game is long over. Jane and Angela come out of the gy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, they're still here. Her POV: Lester and Carolyn stand at the edge of the park lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi! I really enjoyed that! She crosses reluctantly toward her parents, followed by Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, honey, you were great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't win anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Angela) Hi, I'm Lester. Janie's dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hi. An awkward beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my friend, Angela Hayes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, good to meet you. You were also good tonight. Very... precise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warming) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Angela) Nice to meet you, Angela. (to Jane) Honey, I'm so proud of you. I watched you very closely, and you didn't screw up once. (then, to Lester) Okay, we have to go. She starts toward the parking lot. Lester stays behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what are you girls doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going out for pizza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really, do you need a ride? We can give you a ride. I have a car. You wanna come with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks... but I have a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you have a car. Oh. That's great! That's great, because Janie's thinking about getting a car soon too, aren't you, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (you freak) Dad. Mom's waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was very nice meeting you, Angela. Any, uh, friend of Janie's is a friend of mine. Angela smiles, aware of the power she has over him. He is mesmerized; grateful, even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I'll be seeing you around then.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Lester waves awkwardly as he crosses off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could he be any more pathetic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's sweet. And I think he and your mother have not had sex in a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a solitary red ROSE PETAL as it falls slowly thr the air. We're looking down on Lester and Carolyn in bed. Even in sleep, Carolyn looks determined. Lester is awake and star up at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the weirdest thing. The ROSE PETAL drifts into view, landing on his pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I've been in a coma for about twenty years, and I'm just now waking up. More ROSE PETALS fall onto the bed, and he smiles up at.. His POV: Angela, naked, FLOATS above us as a deluge of RO PETALS falls around her. Her hair fans out around her hea and GLOWS with a subtle, burnished light. She looks down us with a smile that is all things... Lester smiles back and LAUGHS, as ROSE PETALS cover his f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spec-tac-ular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WHITE BMW 328si CONVERTIBLE is parked on the street out the Burnham's house. We HEAR girlish LAUGHTER from inside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela is behind the wheel, Jane in the passenger seat. They're passing a JOINT back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry my dad was so weird tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm used to guys drooling over me. It started when I was about twelve, I'd go out to dinner with my parents. Every Thursday night, Red Lobster. And every guy there would stare at me when I walked in. And I knew what they were thinking. Just like I knew guys at school thought about me when they jerked off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vomit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: You know I don't like locked doors in my house, boy. Ricky opens the door. The Colonel stands outside, eyeing
